channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Colombia: A Clash on the Border
item.description: Colombia’s Ministry of Defense said Friday that Colombian rebels were responsible for killing an Ecuadorean Army officer and wounding a soldier during a border skirmish on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: In Cairo Camps, Protesters Dig in and Live On
item.description: Two camps in Cairo set up by supporters of the ousted Egyptian president, Mohamed Morsi, have become the front lines in a dangerous stalemate with the military-installed government.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:credit: Narciso Contreras for The New York Times
item.media:description: A couple who support Egypt’s ousted president, Mohamed Morsi, married Thursday at a protest camp near Cairo University.

item.title: U.S. to Reopen 18 of 19 Closed Embassies
item.description: Most of the American embassies closed this month because of worries about potential terrorist attacks will reopen on Sunday, the State Department said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: Pollution Economics
item.description: China tries a market fix for its dirty air.
item.dc:creator: By DIRK FORRISTER and PAUL BLEDSOE

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: Killing Lions, Buying Bombs
item.description: Tens of thousands of animals are killed each year, with poachers’ profits often being funneled to terrorist groups.
item.dc:creator: By JOHAN BERGENAS, RACHEL STOHL and OCHIENG ADALA

item.title: President Moves to Ease Worries on Surveillance
item.description: President Obama sought to take control of the surveillance debate, releasing a legal justification for domestic spying and calling for more scrutiny of National Security Agency programs.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE and MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: Journalists in Syria Face Dangers of War and Rising Risk of Abduction
item.description: The Committee to Protect Journalists has reported at least 14 journalists who are missing or have been abducted, but the total number of kidnappings is believed to be much higher.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Florence Aubenas spoke last month at a gathering for Didier François and Édouard Elias, fellow French journalists who disappeared near Aleppo, Syria.

item.title: Mexican Tied to Killing of D.E.A. Agent Is Freed
item.description: Rafael Caro Quintero, a drug kingpin convicted of masterminding an American’s death, was unexpectedly released from prison on Friday after his conviction was overturned.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD and KARLA ZABLUDOVSKY
item.media:description: Rafael Caro Quintero, shown in 2005, had served 28 years in prison.

item.title: Chilean President Apologizes for Census
item.description: President Sebastián Piñera apologized for serious mistakes in the nationwide census last year, which, despite intense efforts, failed to survey over 9 percent of the population.
item.dc:creator: By PASCALE BONNEFOY

item.title: Kerry and Hagel Meet With Their Russian Counterparts
item.description: A day of high-level meetings yielded little definite accomplishments, underscoring the many unresolved remaining issues between the two countries.
item.dc:creator: By THOM SHANKER and MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Inquiry Focuses on BBC Severance Payments
item.description: The police in Britain opened an investigation after an audit found departing executives from the British Broadcasting Corporation received more than they were entitled to.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTINE HAUGHNEY and RAVI SOMAIYA

item.title: Kenyan Inquiries Find No Sign of Explosion in Airport Fire, President Says
item.description: President Uhuru Kenyatta said initial investigations had found that “this was a simple fire gone bad.”
item.dc:creator: By REUBEN KYAMA

item.title: Japan’s Debt Looks Like This: 1,000,000,000,000,000 Yen
item.description: Japan’s soaring national debt has reached a new milestone, surpassing one quadrillion yen. That’s a one followed by 15 zeros. The mind boggles.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN SCHWARTZ

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Vote Results Delayed
item.description: The announcement came after the government acknowledged moving armored vehicles and troops into the capital to keep order in the event of a protest by the opposition.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Ascending Heights of French Power, Trailed by Her ‘Otherness’
item.description: Justice Minister Christiane Taubira, who is from French Guiana, is an outspoken woman of color in a position of considerable visibility and influence, in a country where few have come before her.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE
item.media:credit: Stephane Remael for The New York Times
item.media:description: "My conscience is my boss, and my conscience dictates rules that are extremely, I’d say, grand — they’re rough but beautiful," said Christiane Taubira.

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Governments in Central America Mobilize to Fight Dengue Virus
item.description: There have been 120,000 suspected cases of dengue reported across Central America so far in the season.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Thailand: 30 Asylum Seekers Escape From Detention Camp
item.description: More than 1,700 asylum seekers from Myanmar’s Rohingya minority who arrived in Thailand by boat early this year are being held in crowded prisons.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Brazil: Same-Sex Union Victory
item.description: A court in the northeastern state of Pernambuco has ordered Brazil’s Army for the first time to recognize a same-sex civil union between a sergeant and his companion.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: 30-Year Prison Sentence in Plot to Bomb U.S. Bank
item.description: Quazi Mohammad Rezwanul Ahsan Nafis, a Bangladeshi immigrant, received the minimum penalty after pleading guilty to attempting to use a weapon of mass destruction.
item.category: Federal Reserve Bank of New York
item.dc:creator: By MOSI SECRET

item.title: Sinai Blasts Kill Up to 5 Thought to Be Militants
item.description: Reports suggested that the explosions were the result of an Israeli missile strike that had been carried out in coordination with Egypt.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Turkish Pilots Kidnapped by Gunmen in Beirut
item.description: The attack could signal a further spread into Lebanon of the civil war in Syria, but no group immediately took responsibility for the abduction.
item.dc:creator: By HWAIDA SAAD and ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Lebanese army soldiers patrol the road leading to Rafik Hariri International Airport on Friday.

item.title: Zimbabwe Opposition Files Legal Challenge to Nullify Presidential Results
item.description: The Movement for Democratic Change contends that the party of President Robert G. Mugabe rigged the election in order to claim a landslide victory.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN

item.title: Cramming for Stardom at Korea’s K-Pop Schools
item.description: Private institutions have sprung up around the country to teach Korean pop music, and long-established music and dance schools have begun to get with the pop plan.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The International Herald Tribune
item.media:description: Students at Def Dance Skool in Seoul.

item.title: Obama on Embassy Closures and Drones
item.description: President Obama said although Al Qaeda and other terrorist organizations have weakened, they still pose regional threats against businesses and diplomatic outposts.

item.title: Obama on Putin, Snowden and the Olympics
item.description: President Obama said in his press conference that Edward J. Snowden’s asylum offer is only the latest in a long list of actions forcing the administration to question its relationship with Russia.
